description: Domestic and foreign policies, major legislation, crisis management, economic performance, societal impact, and leadership style. Include key achievements, challenges, scandals, and their lasting legacy, providing specific examples to illustrate their impact.

example_output.title: William McKinley
example_output.description: William McKinley is inaugurated as the 25th President of the United States.
example_output.longDescription: William McKinley was inaugurated as the 25th President of the United States on March 4, 1897, bringing a platform of protectionist tariffs and economic recovery after the Panic of 1893. His administration is primarily recognized for its role in the Spanish-American War, which resulted in the U.S. acquiring territories such as Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines. Despite initial economic growth, McKinley faced mounting opposition, culminating in his assassination in 1901.
example_output.imagePrompt: A forward-looking inauguration of William McKinley, with banners, cheering crowds, and veterans of the Civil War saluting.

example_output.title: Theodore Roosevelt
example_output.description: Theodore Roosevelt becomes the 26th President after McKinley's assassination.
example_output.longDescription: Theodore Roosevelt assumed the presidency on September 14, 1901, following the assassination of William McKinley. Known for his energetic personality and progressive reforms, Roosevelt emphasized trust-busting and conservation, leading to monumental changes in American society. His administration saw the establishment of national parks and the initiation of significant regulatory measures against monopolies. Roosevelt became a central figure in shaping American domestic and foreign policies, steering the nation towards a new era of modernization and global involvement.
example_output.imagePrompt: An iconic scene with Theodore Roosevelt being sworn in with determination, surrounded by dignitaries and supporters during a tense time in history.

example_output.title: William Howard Taft
example_output.description: William Howard Taft takes office as the 27th President of the United States.
example_output.longDescription: William Howard Taft was inaugurated as the 27th President of the United States on March 4, 1909, succeeding Theodore Roosevelt. His presidency focused on continued progressive reforms, including establishing the Department of Labor and implementing antitrust regulations. However, Taft's administration faced significant challenges, including a growing split within the Republican Party that ultimately led to the rise of progressive factions and his eventual loss to Woodrow Wilson in the 1912 election. Taft's legacy is complex, as he later became the only person to serve as Chief Justice of the United States after his presidency.
example_output.imagePrompt: A dignified inauguration ceremony of William Howard Taft, with a tall figure in a top hat standing at the podium before a large, expectant crowd.
